2017-11-17.abstract: The first ultra-Orthodox woman elected judge in the country got there not by breaking the rules of her community, but by observing them religiously.
2017-11-17.snippet: The first ultra-Orthodox woman elected judge in the country got there not by breaking the rules of her community, but by observing them religiously.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Just before the Jewish High Holy Days this fall, Judge Rachel Freier was rushing around her kitchen, as she perpetually is. She had just cooked a salmon dish for Sabbath dinner. She was talking to her daughter in Israel on her headset. She was at a countertop, cutting apples and wrapping tuna salad sandwiches to take to work, because at night court in Brooklyn, where she presides, there’s little to eat that’s kosher.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Judge Ruchie, the Hasidic Superwoman of Night Court

2017-11-17.abstract: A couples vacation before becoming a parent is a chance to relax, spend quality time with your partner and indulge in some fun before parenthood hits.
2017-11-17.snippet: A couples vacation before becoming a parent is a chance to relax, spend quality time with your partner and indulge in some fun before parenthood hits.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: A babymoon — a vacation couples take in the months before they become parents — is a chance to relax, spend quality time with your partner and indulge in some fun before your new arrival, said Sherry Alvarado, the experiences coordinator at Rosewood Bermuda. Ms. Alvarado has planned more than 100 babymoons over the last several years for couples who have stayed at the resort and has plenty of tips on how to make this last pre-parent hurrah a trip to remember. Here, she shares some tips on making the most of yours.
2017-11-17.headline_main: How to Get the Most Out of Your Babymoon

2017-11-17.abstract: How a partisan lens leads people to different interpretations of the same facts.
2017-11-17.snippet: How a partisan lens leads people to different interpretations of the same facts.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: It may feel to Americans that an intense state of us-versus-them is something new,  but it’s not. People have been using party as a lens to filter information for decades and beyond.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Bill Clinton, Roy Moore and the Power of Social Identity

2017-11-17.abstract: A Belgian Malinois dog called Mali has received Britain’s highest award for animal valor for his actions during an intense firefight in Afghanistan.
2017-11-17.snippet: A Belgian Malinois dog called Mali has received Britain’s highest award for animal valor for his actions during an intense firefight in Afghanistan.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: War has long made heroes of women and men. But animals have also shown gallantry in battle stretching back centuries, including dogs, bears, cats, a duck and even a goat called Sergeant Bill.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Dog Earns Special Treat: British Award for Bravery

2017-11-17.abstract: Looming defeat has set the GOP free to be the terrible party it always wanted to be.
2017-11-17.snippet: Looming defeat has set the GOP free to be the terrible party it always wanted to be.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: These are not good times, politically, for Republicans. The Virginia blowout showed that the Trump backlash is real, and will show up in actual votes, not just polls. A series of local elections have produced Democratic victories in hitherto deep-red regions. Despite gerrymandering and the inherent disadvantage caused by concentration of minority voters in urban districts, Democrats are probably mild favorites to take the House; thanks to Roy Moore, they even have a chance of taking the Senate, despite what was supposed to be an impossible map. “A wave is a’ coming” says the Cook Political Report.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Days of Greed and Desperation

2017-11-17.abstract: The opposition politician Raila Odinga returned from abroad, and his supporters fought with the police.
2017-11-17.snippet: The opposition politician Raila Odinga returned from abroad, and his supporters fought with the police.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Several people were killed on Friday in clashes between the Kenyan police and supporters of the opposition politician Raila Odinga after a disputed contest in which President Uhuru Kenyatta was re-elected, despite reports of voting irregularities.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Political Clashes in Kenya Leave Several Dead

2017-11-17.abstract: Topped with bacon and eggs, it’s perfect for breakfast or brunch, and even goes well with coffee.
2017-11-17.snippet: Topped with bacon and eggs, it’s perfect for breakfast or brunch, and even goes well with coffee.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Eating leftover pizza for breakfast is a time-honored tradition. Whether you prefer it cold and a little soggy, straight from the box, or heated in a skillet or broiler until the cheese bubbles, pizza is a near-perfect antidote to whatever kept you up way too late the night before in the first place.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Pizza for Breakfast, but Not What You Think

2017-11-17.abstract: Thanksgiving is coming. Make your plan, then settle in for some lamb and white bean chili or pasta with cauliflower and capers.
2017-11-17.snippet: Thanksgiving is coming. Make your plan, then settle in for some lamb and white bean chili or pasta with cauliflower and capers.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.
2017-11-17.headline_main: What to Cook This Weekend

2017-11-17.abstract: If you don’t think right-wing politics should dominate Christian life, where can you find the right congregation?
2017-11-17.snippet: If you don’t think right-wing politics should dominate Christian life, where can you find the right congregation?
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Kaitlyn Schiess has a sterling evangelical pedigree. She grew up in evangelical churches in Colorado and Virginia and graduated from Liberty University before entering Dallas Theological Seminary last year to prepare for a career in the church. But lately she has been frustrated by evangelicals’ failure to challenge the prejudice and predation in their midst. Over the course of the week, as Roy Moore, the Republican senatorial candidate in Alabama, faced more allegations of inappropriate sexual contact with young women and teenagers, many evangelicals leapt to his defense.
2017-11-17.headline_main: How to Escape From Roy Moore’s Evangelicalism

2017-11-17.abstract: C.B. Cebulski is named editor in chief of Marvel Entertainment. Axel Alonso departs.
2017-11-17.snippet: C.B. Cebulski is named editor in chief of Marvel Entertainment. Axel Alonso departs.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Marvel Entertainment, the home of Captain America, Spider-Man and the X-Men, among other colorful heroes, is undergoing a change in leadership. The company released a statement Friday announcing the appointment of C. B. Cebulski as editor in chief. Mr. Cebulski is replacing Axel Alonso, who served in that role since 2011 and is leaving Marvel.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Marvel Entertainment Names New Editor in Chief

2017-11-17.abstract: “Thaïs” at the Met and “The Mother of Us All” in Hudson, N.Y., are unlikely partners in reflecting the difficult realities of female lives.
2017-11-17.snippet: “Thaïs” at the Met and “The Mother of Us All” in Hudson, N.Y., are unlikely partners in reflecting the difficult realities of female lives.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: There could hardly be two operas less similar than “Thaïs” and “The Mother of Us All.”

2017-11-17.abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week:Elizabeth Hardwick on the art and meaning of the essay.
2017-11-17.snippet: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week:Elizabeth Hardwick on the art and meaning of the essay.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: In this issue Hermione Hoby reviews a new collection of Elizabeth Hardwick’s essays. In this 1986 piece, originally printed in “The Best American Essays,” Hardwick meditates on the art and meaning of the essay in American life. Read an excerpt below:
2017-11-17.headline_main: Notes From the Book Review Archives

2017-11-17.abstract: A daylong debate over taxes devolved into an angry shouting match as Senators Orrin Hatch and Sherrod Brown sparred over whether the bill favored the rich.
2017-11-17.snippet: A daylong debate over taxes devolved into an angry shouting match as Senators Orrin Hatch and Sherrod Brown sparred over whether the bill favored the rich.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: As the $1.5 trillion tax cut sailed through the House on Thursday along party lines, the Senate Finance Committee was beset by sharp exchanges between Republicans and Democrats, who spent an arduous day trying — and failing — to change a bill they said would favor corporations and the rich over everyone else.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Tax Fight Gets Personal as Senators Spar Over Bill

2017-11-17.abstract: Island states that are least responsible for global emissions but most vulnerable to storms and rising seas are looking outside the United Nations process for aid.
2017-11-17.snippet: Island states that are least responsible for global emissions but most vulnerable to storms and rising seas are looking outside the United Nations process for aid.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Want the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Island Nations, With No Time to Lose, Take Climate Response Into Their Own Hands

2017-11-17.abstract: How does an elite industry continue to thrive in a world that increasingly revolts against the trappings of luxury? Francesca Bellettini of Saint Laurent, Alexander Gilkes of Paddle8 and Laura Pancera of UBS spoke with Elizabeth Paton, European Styles Correspondent at The New York Times's International Luxury Conference.

Francesca Bellettini of Saint Laurent, Alexander Gilkes of Paddle8 and Laura Pancera of UBS spoke with Elizabeth Paton, European Styles Correspondent at The New York Times's International Luxury Conference.

2017-11-17.abstract: When the dust settles after the holiday, here’s what to make with leftover bread, squash, greens, onions and (almost) anything else.
2017-11-17.snippet: When the dust settles after the holiday, here’s what to make with leftover bread, squash, greens, onions and (almost) anything else.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: The fight against food waste is not a new one. Stale bread, for instance, has long been precious in bread-eating cultures, where to waste even a slice is a kind of sin. A hard baguette, a loaf that’s too dry to cut, even the leftover heels and crusts: all have potential in the kitchen.
2017-11-17.headline_main: A New Life for Thanksgiving Ingredients

2017-11-17.abstract: The rapper made a homecoming to the borough where he was raised, visiting the spots where he and his friends would shop and try to talk to girls.
2017-11-17.snippet: The rapper made a homecoming to the borough where he was raised, visiting the spots where he and his friends would shop and try to talk to girls.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Karim Kharbouch, better known by his stage name French Montana, was getting dressed at the Gansevoort Park Avenue hotel, where he was staying while touring with the Weeknd. Six necklaces, two chain bracelets, a watch and a ruby ring — each dripping in diamonds — were laid out on a towel before him.
2017-11-17.headline_main: French Montana Shops for Tracksuits and Timberlands in the Bronx

2017-11-17.abstract: As foreign minister, Margot Wallstrom, who broke free from a violent relationship in her 20s, is challenging assumptions in a traditionally male sphere.
2017-11-17.snippet: As foreign minister, Margot Wallstrom, who broke free from a violent relationship in her 20s, is challenging assumptions in a traditionally male sphere.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — More than three decades ago, in a town in Sweden, a man grabbed his girlfriend by the hair and threw her against a wardrobe door with such force that a clump of hair came off in his hand.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Sweden’s Proponent of ‘Feminist Foreign Policy,’ Shaped by Abuse

2017-11-17.abstract: Tax cuts that give rich people more money aren’t good for anyone, including the rich. Believing it will help them buy special things is a cognitive error.
2017-11-17.snippet: Tax cuts that give rich people more money aren’t good for anyone, including the rich. Believing it will help them buy special things is a cognitive error.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: The Republican effort to cut federal taxes is still underway, and many crucial details are still unsettled. But little doubt remains that the effort has been heavily shaped by wealthy donors.
2017-11-17.headline_main: How Cutting Taxes Makes Life Worse for the Rich

2017-11-17.abstract: For its 100th anniversary, the N.H.L. commissioned an Ottawa artist to paint all of the players voted as the top 100 in the league’s history.
2017-11-17.snippet: For its 100th anniversary, the N.H.L. commissioned an Ottawa artist to paint all of the players voted as the top 100 in the league’s history.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A hundred years after the National Hockey League was born in Montreal’s grandest hotel, the Windsor, the league is back where it all began this weekend.
2017-11-17.headline_main: The N.H.L. Needed 100 Portraits. So Tony Harris Got to Work.

2017-11-17.abstract: The administration is lifting a ban on importing elephant parts severed as trophies after the animals are shot in Zimbabwe.
2017-11-17.snippet: The administration is lifting a ban on importing elephant parts severed as trophies after the animals are shot in Zimbabwe.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Update: On Friday evening, President Trump tweeted that he would leave the ban in place, pending further review.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Trump Bags Another Anti-Obama Trophy: Dead Elephants

2017-11-17.abstract: GAC Motor wants to lead an export push as China prepares the rest of its auto industry to go global and, in particular, target the American market.

2017-11-17.abstract: Subspecies of the flowers share most of their genes, but differ in a handful that lead to some being yellow on magenta and others being magenta on yellow.
2017-11-17.snippet: Subspecies of the flowers share most of their genes, but differ in a handful that lead to some being yellow on magenta and others being magenta on yellow.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: In the Pyrenees Mountains between France and Spain, wild snapdragons bloom each spring.
2017-11-17.headline_main: How Snapdragons Beckon Bees With More Than One Color

2017-11-17.abstract: Watch a musical portrait of Josephine Baker and an opera based on a musicology classic — highlights of Thomas W. Morris’s reign at Ojai, which ends in 2019.
2017-11-17.snippet: Watch a musical portrait of Josephine Baker and an opera based on a musicology classic — highlights of Thomas W. Morris’s reign at Ojai, which ends in 2019.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Change is coming to the Ojai Musical Festival, which celebrates contemporary music in an idyllic California valley each year: its artistic director, Thomas W. Morris, announced Friday that he would retire in 2019 after 16 years of guiding, and broadening, the festival.
2017-11-17.headline_main: With Change Coming to the Ojai Festival, Watch What Makes it Unusual

2017-11-17.abstract: The remains of the day provide ingredients for three more days of meals that invite you to tinker and try new dishes.
2017-11-17.snippet: The remains of the day provide ingredients for three more days of meals that invite you to tinker and try new dishes.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: In that pause before pie, when the bulk of the Thanksgiving meal is over and it’s time to stack gravy-smeared plates and carry them to the sink, every cook is happy.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Here Comes the Best Part of Thanksgiving: Leftovers

2017-11-17.abstract: As anti-immigrant sentiments spread and natural disasters have torn through Latin America, the awards became a showcase for Latin pride and solidarity.
2017-11-17.snippet: As anti-immigrant sentiments spread and natural disasters have torn through Latin America, the awards became a showcase for Latin pride and solidarity.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Awards shows are made for promotion, self-congratulation, flashy fashion and industrywide solidarity. The 18th Latin Grammy Awards, broadcast on Thursday night by Univision from the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, had all of those. But as politicians have exploited anti-immigrant sentiments and as hurricanes and earthquakes have torn through Latin America, the Latin Grammys have also taken on a second role: as a showcase for pride, achievement and solidarity.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Puerto Rico Mattered at the Latin Grammys. So Did Salsa.

2017-11-17.abstract: Britain’s Prince William and Prince Harry will play Stormtroopers in a scene in an installment of the new trilogy, The Hollywood Reporter says.
2017-11-17.snippet: Britain’s Prince William and Prince Harry will play Stormtroopers in a scene in an installment of the new trilogy, The Hollywood Reporter says.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The empire really will strike back, with British royalty set to be part of the coming “Star Wars” film. Prince William and Prince Harry will make cameos in “Star Wars: The Last Jedi” (due Dec. 15), the film’s lead actor John Boyega has told The Hollywood Reporter.
2017-11-17.headline_main: ‘Star Wars’ Royalty: Princes Said to Have Cameo in Film

2017-11-17.abstract: A pre-Iron Bowl break is a tradition for Alabama’s best teams, but using it to attack the team’s schedule is misguided.

2017-11-17.abstract: The White House’s latest disaster relief request pushed the total from this year’s hurricanes and wildfires close to $100 billion, but it came with suggested cuts.
2017-11-17.snippet: The White House’s latest disaster relief request pushed the total from this year’s hurricanes and wildfires close to $100 billion, but it came with suggested cuts.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House asked Congress on Friday for $44 billion in additional relief in response to this year’s devastating hurricanes, but facing rising budget deficits and pushing a tax cut that could cost $1.5 trillion, the administration also suggested that lawmakers make spending cuts to offset disaster costs.
2017-11-17.headline_main: White House Requests More Disaster Aid but Also Seeks Cuts as Deficits Rise

2017-11-17.abstract: Two-thirds admit to streaming movies and TV shows outside the home. And 12 percent who watch in public have done so in public restrooms.
2017-11-17.snippet: Two-thirds admit to streaming movies and TV shows outside the home. And 12 percent who watch in public have done so in public restrooms.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Behold the versatile public restroom: It’s a refuge, a place to steel one’s nerves and, for some, a personal theater.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Americans Are Watching Netflix at Work and in the Bathroom

2017-11-17.abstract: Dire predictions of a flu pandemic proved overblown in 2005 and 2009. Still, health officials are warning that the H7N9 virus, which can be lethal, is on the rise.
2017-11-17.snippet: Dire predictions of a flu pandemic proved overblown in 2005 and 2009. Still, health officials are warning that the H7N9 virus, which can be lethal, is on the rise.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: While trying to avoid alarmism, global health agencies are steadily ratcheting up concern about bird flu in Asia. Bird viruses that can infect humans — particularly those of the H7N9 strain — continue to spread to new cities there.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Bird Flu Is Spreading in Asia, Experts (Quietly) Warn

2017-11-17.abstract: With the help of a “run right” board and a conveyor for traveling between floors, a shift lead keeps processes at Quaker Oats running smoothly.
2017-11-17.snippet: With the help of a “run right” board and a conveyor for traveling between floors, a shift lead keeps processes at Quaker Oats running smoothly.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Charlie Mossman, 61, a shift lead, keeps the daytime oat milling operation running fluidly at Quaker Oats Company in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Milling 66 Acres of Oats (Every Hour) Without a Hitch

2017-11-17.abstract: It was Russia’s second veto in 24 hours aimed at protecting the Syrian government and Russia’s 11th veto to shield Syria since the war began in 2011.

2017-11-17.headline_main: Search Underway for Argentine Navy Submarine With 44 Aboard

2017-11-17.snippet: South Korean doctors operating on an injured North Korean soldier found parasites in his digestive tract, a symptom of poor hygiene and nutrition.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A North Korean soldier’s bold attempt to defect by crossing the heavily guarded border with South Korea galvanized attention this week.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Surgery Reveals North Korean Defector Is Riddled With Parasitic Worms

2017-11-17.abstract: Life and death, joy and poverty coexist in Emma Dante’s wondrous show about a family in Palermo. And it only costs $20 to see it.
2017-11-17.snippet: Life and death, joy and poverty coexist in Emma Dante’s wondrous show about a family in Palermo. And it only costs $20 to see it.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Look how much fun the Macaluso girls are having, how well they get along. There they are, ribbing and pinching each other, jostling and laughing. Their hair is wild, their smiles are wide. But, as we discover, their pain, sadness and anger run deep.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Review: A Raucous Day at the Beach With ‘The Sisters Macaluso’

2017-11-17.abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
2017-11-17.snippet: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: One of the wisest, savviest museum exhibitions of the summer (it closes Dec. 17) may not have much actual art, but it circles the subject like a satellite. Using prints, slide shows, books and iPads, it presents image-only camera-phone exchanges between 12 pairs of artists, and is full of flashes of wit, poetry, even genius. ROBERTA SMITH
2017-11-17.headline_main: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now

2017-11-17.abstract: A guide to the label’s catalog, which encompasses jazz, classical music and cross-cultural fusions.
2017-11-17.snippet: A guide to the label’s catalog, which encompasses jazz, classical music and cross-cultural fusions.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Sound quality has always mattered to Manfred Eicher, the meticulous and exploratory producer who founded ECM (Edition of Contemporary Music) Records in 1969 and has produced the vast majority of its recordings. ECM has released an extraordinary catalog that encompasses jazz, classical music and cross-cultural fusions from composers and performers like Keith Jarrett, Vijay Iyer, Arvo Pärt and Meredith Monk. Across styles, the label’s hallmark has been the contemplative detail of its music, a kind of acoustic enhanced realism.
2017-11-17.headline_main: ECM’s Catalog Is Finally Streaming. Here Are 21 Essential Albums.

2017-11-17.abstract: Apply to win a reporting trip to the developing world.
2017-11-17.snippet: Apply to win a reporting trip to the developing world.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: I’m delighted to invite university students to apply for my 2018 win-a-trip contest. I’ve been holding these contests since 2006, and taking the winner along with me on a reporting trip to cover global poverty and social justice issues. My aim is to generate interest in neglected global issues and get more people writing about them.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Win a Trip in 2018!

2017-11-17.abstract: Two new works by the choreographers Marjani Forté-Saunders and Gillian Walsh make dramatic use of the Manhattan spaces in which they are performed.
2017-11-17.snippet: Two new works by the choreographers Marjani Forté-Saunders and Gillian Walsh make dramatic use of the Manhattan spaces in which they are performed.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Two courageously unusual pieces have opened this week, both by female choreographers. In each case, the singularity starts with the location and the use of light.

2017-11-17.snippet: President Trump wants to cut taxes and reduce the nation’s trade deficit, two goals that stand in direct conflict with each other.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has promised to cut federal taxes and reduce the nation’s trade deficit with the rest of world — two economic priorities that are in direct conflict with each other.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Trump’s Tax Cuts Are Likely to Increase Trade Deficit

2017-11-17.abstract: Before Harvey Fierstein came along, most gay-themed plays featured characters who were either closeted or bitter or suicidal, and usually all three.
2017-11-17.snippet: Before Harvey Fierstein came along, most gay-themed plays featured characters who were either closeted or bitter or suicidal, and usually all three.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning in the fall of 1981, I was sitting in my fourth-floor walk-up studio apartment in the Yorkville neighborhood of Manhattan, flipping through that day’s New York Times, when I was struck by a theater review that ran on one of the far back pages of the news section. Its headline was simple enough: “Fierstein’s ‘Torch Song.’” But what followed was anything but.
2017-11-17.headline_main: ‘Torch Song Trilogy’ and Me: A 35-Year Love Affair

2017-11-17.headline_main: We Should All Learn the Constitution

2017-11-17.abstract: Biologists studied cormorants and penguins that hunt fish in frigid seas and found that cormorants save energy by only moving their necks when seizing prey.
2017-11-17.snippet: Biologists studied cormorants and penguins that hunt fish in frigid seas and found that cormorants save energy by only moving their necks when seizing prey.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: It was a question that dogged biologists, Agustina Gómez-Laich recalls: Why the neck?
2017-11-17.headline_main: Same Oceans, Similar Prey, Two Very Different Necks

2017-11-17.abstract: The state is the first to have businesses that don’t offer their own plans automatically enroll workers for a payroll deduction. Workers can opt out.
2017-11-17.snippet: The state is the first to have businesses that don’t offer their own plans automatically enroll workers for a payroll deduction. Workers can opt out.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: The lack of retirement savings among Americans is almost universally bemoaned but nudging, prodding and lecturing have done little to build up nest eggs for old age. So some states say they are going to make it easier to save with a simple plan: an automatic payroll deduction for retirement savings.
2017-11-17.headline_main: In Oregon, You Can Now Save for Retirement. Unless You Object.

2017-11-17.abstract: Hear the tracks that caught our critics' attention this week, from two Spanish-English team-ups to a surprise from Jaden Smith.
2017-11-17.snippet: Hear the tracks that caught our critics' attention this week, from two Spanish-English team-ups to a surprise from Jaden Smith.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, something new from the 82-year-old trombonist Roswell Rudd, a video from the Latin Grammy winner for best new artist and a surprise album from Jaden Smith.
2017-11-17.headline_main: The Playlist: Demi Lovato Seeks Her ‘Despacito’ and 9 More New Songs

2017-11-17.abstract: Whether in “Dance in America” or “Dirty Dancing,” Mr. Bhargava’s eye and sense of musicality were highly prized in translating dance to film.
2017-11-17.snippet: Whether in “Dance in America” or “Dirty Dancing,” Mr. Bhargava’s eye and sense of musicality were highly prized in translating dance to film.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Girish Bhargava, who was a master of the underappreciated art of editing dance films and put that skill to use on the hit movie “Dirty Dancing” and numerous episodes of the PBS series “Dance in America,” died on Nov. 11 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 76.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Girish Bhargava, Film Editor Who Captured Dance, Dies at 76

2017-11-17.abstract: A provision in the House and Senate tax bills will change, but not close, the so-called carried interest tax loophole, which benefits wealthy people.
2017-11-17.snippet: A provision in the House and Senate tax bills will change, but not close, the so-called carried interest tax loophole, which benefits wealthy people.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: The authors of the Senate’s proposed $1.5 trillion tax cut bill did no more than their House counterparts to close a contentious tax loophole favored by managers of private equity firms and some real estate ventures.

2017-11-17.snippet: The Trump administration’s signals have hurt Time Warner shares. But there is money to be made if last month’s pricing was more accurate than today’s.

2017-11-17.abstract: Benedict Allen was trying to reconnect with a tribe he had met 30 years ago.

2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: “Don’t try to rescue me, please,” Benedict Allen, 57, tweeted as he set off into the wilderness of Papua New Guinea to track down a remote group he first met 30 years earlier. “Where I’m going in PNG you won’t ever find me.”
2017-11-17.headline_main: British Explorer Is Rescued From Remote Forest in Papua New Guinea

2017-11-17.snippet: His trip was a major embarrassment for President Nicolás Maduro, who has sought to silence opponents.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Antonio Ledezma, a prominent opposition leader in Venezuela who had been placed under house arrest on sedition charges, escaped on Friday morning and fled to neighboring Colombia, where the authorities allowed him to enter.
2017-11-17.headline_main: Antonio Ledezma, Venezuelan Opposition Leader, Flees to Colombia

2017-11-17.abstract: An exhibition at the Institut du Monde Arabe in Paris looks at 2,000 years of Christians in the Arab World. It has a message for France — and for us all.
2017-11-17.snippet: An exhibition at the Institut du Monde Arabe in Paris looks at 2,000 years of Christians in the Arab World. It has a message for France — and for us all.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Behind the famous dilating windows Jean Nouvel designed for its Seine-side home, the Institut du Monde Arabe has presented a string of recent shows that have deepened and diversified France’s understanding of Islam. From “The Thousand and One Nights” (2012) to “Hajj: The Pilgrimage to Mecca” (2014) and the epic “Ocean Explorers” (2016), exhibitions here have disclosed the breadth of Islamic culture and history, and their intimate, centuries-long links with the West.
2017-11-17.headline_main: What Christian Artifacts of the Middle East Can Show Us About Tolerance

2017-11-17.abstract: Dr. Raines and his wife were among the antiwar protesters who broke into a field office in 1971 and stole hundreds of files, which they gave to journalists.
2017-11-17.snippet: Dr. Raines and his wife were among the antiwar protesters who broke into a field office in 1971 and stole hundreds of files, which they gave to journalists.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: One day in May 1971, John C. Raines, a religion professor at Temple University, had just returned to his home in Germantown, Pa., from playing tennis when two F.B.I. agents knocked on the door.
2017-11-17.headline_main: John Raines, 84, Who Evaded Capture in an F.B.I. Break-in, Dies

2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lisa Eisner is trying to get us killed. We are in her Lexus wagon, slicing through three lanes of high-speed traffic from Interstate 605 at the Interstate 5 interchange. I am daydreaming vaguely about another Los Angeles road scene: barefoot Mariah Wyeth in her Camaro and the famous Hollywood to Harbor freeway lane-change passage in “Play It as It Lays.”

2017-11-17.abstract: This Thanksgiving, a prayer for finding fellowship across our divided kitchens.
2017-11-17.snippet: This Thanksgiving, a prayer for finding fellowship across our divided kitchens.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I visited friends in rural Virginia. I cherish them because we have little in common other than our like-mindedness. Susan, a historian, is 11 years older than I am and has four children to my zero. I grew up among atheist Soviet Jews; she among evangelical Christians. Susan was home-schooled and married Pete, a pastor. I’ve remained unmarried for so long even my mother has surrendered.
2017-11-17.headline_main: God Is in the Salad Dressing

With Google Earth’s satellite imagery at his fingertips, the archaeologist peeked at burial sites and other so-called Works of the Old Men, created by nomadic tribes thousands of years ago.

For the house’s 10th installation at the annual fair, it asked the up-and-coming Italian industrial designer Chiara Andreatti to create an elegant living room environment, called Welcome!, that pays homage to the maison’s iconic fashion pieces — but with a whisper. “The links are very subtle,” Andreatti says. “Not shouted.”

2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Ten intolerable days after Hurricane Maria trounced Puerto Rico, Sahria Garcia finally got a call from her brother on the island. 2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: LONDON — And the winner, by a wide margin, for the most comfortable seat in theatergoing in this city can be found in London County Hall. Veteran playgoers who wind up in that stately building’s Council Chamber, where a site-specific production of Agatha Christie’s “Witness for the Prosecution” has become a novelty hit, may experience the giddy sensation of being upgraded from coach to business class on a trans-Atlantic flight.

2017-11-17.abstract: Qualified renters at the upper range of the subsidized housing market have been hard to find, leaving units in some buildings empty as shelters are full.
2017-11-17.snippet: Qualified renters at the upper range of the subsidized housing market have been hard to find, leaving units in some buildings empty as shelters are full.
2017-11-17.lead_paragraph: In any given week, the housing crisis in New York City reveals itself through new but familiar anecdotes of deprivation, in fresh sets of grim statistics, in staggering contradictions. Several days ago, residents of the notoriously beleaguered Louis H. Pink Houses in the East New York section of Brooklyn rallied to protest a lack of heat and hot water in the buildings, a recurring condition, they said, that left children sleeping in parkas and hats and getting sick. Not long after, a report from the city’s Department of Investigation revealed that over a four-year period beginning in 2013, the Housing Authority failed to conduct mandatory lead paint inspections in its apartments but then falsely certified to the federal government that it had, potentially jeopardizing the health of young children of more than 4,000 families. Overcrowding in apartments of all kinds is escalating as well.
2017-11-17.headline_main: At $3,700 a Month, ‘Affordable’ Apartments Go Begging

2017-11-18.snippet: Caryn B. Davis, a photographer, captures the warmth of the winter holiday season in her new book “A Connecticut Christmas.”
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: The photographer Caryn B. Davis visited 40 towns during the two years she spent working on the book “A Connecticut Christmas,” which was published in October: Essex, for the holiday model train show at the Connecticut River Museum and the tastefully decorated bar and dining room at the Griswold Inn. East Haddam, for the Victorian-themed decorations at the Gillette Castle, designed by the playwright and actor William Gillette, who was best known for his portrayal of Sherlock Holmes in the early 20th century. Hartford, for the Mark Twain House & Museum. And Bethlehem (really!) for the 18th-century Neapolitan crèche at the Abbey of Regina Laudis.
2017-11-18.headline_main: In Connecticut, a Quintessential Christmas

2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — Rahimullah served in the Afghan Army for two years, deployed to the bloody front lines of the southern province of Helmand. When he quit, it was not because of the combat: It was when the Taliban went after his family back home, telling them that if he didn’t leave the army there would be a fine of one Kalashnikov rifle, seven cartridge magazines and $1,000 — or worse.

2017-11-18.abstract: Ethiopia is one of the more exciting places to visit in the world right now: An attractive mix of ancient tradition and rapid modernization.
2017-11-18.snippet: Ethiopia is one of the more exciting places to visit in the world right now: An attractive mix of ancient tradition and rapid modernization.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: The man, carrying a basket dripping with blood and slick with fresh entrails, was yelling. The sun had set, and in the empty dirt lot north of the old town of Harar, Ethiopia, where a dozen or so people had gathered, the only light came from yellowish headlamps of an old SUV. The man repeated a high-pitched shriek that lasted a good four or five seconds, something between a mournful wail and a yodel. After a minute of silence, we heard light, quick footsteps. I saw a sullen, hunched-over silhouette, then a pair of glowing eyes. Then two pairs. Hyenas.
2017-11-18.headline_main: A Trip Through the Stunning, Rock-Hewed Churches of Ethiopia

2017-11-18.abstract: Francis Mallmann has become a legend in South America. Does his new restaurant in a Provençal village live up?
2017-11-18.snippet: Francis Mallmann has become a legend in South America. Does his new restaurant in a Provençal village live up?
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: If food lovers gleaned anything about Francis Mallmann from the 2015 “Chef’s Table” episode that chronicled his culinary journey, it’s that the peripatetic Argentine chef finds joy in open flames and remote locales. He runs restaurants in rural Uruguay, in the heart of Chile’s Colchagua Valley, at the edge of the Andes Mountains and resides full time in the wilds of Patagonia. In May, he took his brand of cooking — equal parts rustic and sophisticated — to Le Puy-Sainte-Réparade, a village in Provence, where he opened a 90-seat restaurant, his first in Europe, on the grounds of Château La Coste, an organic wine domaine and contemporary art park.
2017-11-18.headline_main: An Argentine Chef Brings His Fire-Obsessed Cuisine to Rural France

2017-11-18.abstract: Years of conflict have torn at the seams of Juba, South Sudan. But the city’s people hold their heads high.
2017-11-18.snippet: Years of conflict have torn at the seams of Juba, South Sudan. But the city’s people hold their heads high.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: In South Sudan, street photography is essentially illegal. It is another casualty of the civil war. Young, fit, twitchy soldiers are everywhere, ready to crack down on anyone who pulls out a camera. No reasons are ever given and no laws are on the books specifically banning photography, but security services across the country have arrested photographers and roughed them up for taking even the most innocent pictures, like a shot of women baking bread.
2017-11-18.headline_main: What War Can’t Destroy

2017-11-18.abstract: Philip Baker admitted that he defrauded his hedge-fund clients. He was sentenced to 20 years in federal prison. Then he devised an escape plan.
2017-11-18.snippet: Philip Baker admitted that he defrauded his hedge-fund clients. He was sentenced to 20 years in federal prison. Then he devised an escape plan.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Forty inmates lined up for the daily mail call at the Fort Dix Federal Correctional Institution, a complex of low-slung brick buildings in the middle of New Jersey.
2017-11-18.headline_main: A Hedge Fund Manager Committed Fraud. Would the U.S. Let Him Go?

2017-11-18.abstract: Tens of thousands of people marched alongside soldiers on tanks and called for President Robert Mugabe to step down after a military takeover.
2017-11-18.snippet: Tens of thousands of people marched alongside soldiers on tanks and called for President Robert Mugabe to step down after a military takeover.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Tens of thousands of Zimbabweans gathered in the capital on Saturday, hooting, whistling and hugging soldiers as they called for President Robert Mugabe to give up power, days after the military placed him under house arrest.
2017-11-18.headline_main: ‘Mugabe Must Go’: Thousands in Zimbabwe Rally Against Leader

2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: For much of his five-decade career, the metalwork sculptor Albert Paley had planned to create a foundation that would foster scholarship about his work. At his studio in Rochester, N.Y., he set aside artworks with his typical ribbon and shard motifs for that future organization’s collection. This year, he decided instead to sell those objects, partly to avoid the laborious process of setting up a new nonprofit entity. “I’m just trying to simplify things,” Mr. Paley said.
2017-11-18.headline_main: Albert Paley Selling a Sampling of His Metalwork

2017-11-18.snippet: An accord that tried to curb attacks in rebel-held areas has been touted as a crucial step in ending the long civil war. But increasingly, that deal is failing.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A resurgence of deadly attacks by pro-government forces in so-called de-escalation zones in Syria, including a triple airstrike on a busy marketplace that killed more than 50 people, is undermining an agreement portrayed by its sponsors as a crucial step toward ending the six-and-a-half-year civil war.

2017-11-18.snippet: The president is pushing for repairs to the nation’s crumbling infrastructure, and he has promised to streamline government approvals. It still might not be enough.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: President Trump says he is frustrated with the slow pace of major construction projects like highways, ports and pipelines. Last summer, he pledged to use the power of the presidency to jump start building when it became bogged down in administrative delays.

2017-11-18.abstract: 25 years ago scientists raised the threat of climate change. Did I act immediately and decisively? Um, I did not.
2017-11-18.snippet: 25 years ago scientists raised the threat of climate change. Did I act immediately and decisively? Um, I did not.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: Boise, Idaho — Twenty-five years ago this month, more than 1,500 prominent scientists, including over half of the living Nobel laureates, issued a manifesto titled “World Scientists’ Warning to Humanity” in which they admonished, “A great change in our stewardship of the earth and the life on it is required if vast human misery is to be avoided and our global home on this planet is not to be irretrievably mutilated.”
2017-11-18.headline_main: Anthony Doerr: We Were Warned

2017-11-18.abstract: Revisiting the 1990s and realizing that impeachment was reasonable.
2017-11-18.snippet: Revisiting the 1990s and realizing that impeachment was reasonable.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: In the longstanding liberal narrative about Bill Clinton and his scandals, the one pushed by Clinton courtiers and ratified in media coverage of his post-presidency, our 42nd president was only guilty of being a horndog, his affairs were nobody’s business but his family’s, and oral sex with Monica Lewinsky was a small thing that should never have put his presidency in peril.
2017-11-18.headline_main: What if Ken Starr Was Right?

2017-11-18.abstract: My classmates practically booked their flights home during the first week of class. I’d never even heard of green bean casserole.
2017-11-18.snippet: My classmates practically booked their flights home during the first week of class. I’d never even heard of green bean casserole.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — In 1999, I had been a freshman in college in upstate New York for maybe two weeks — it was still September, no one had gotten winter jackets out yet — when my classmates started booking their flights home for Thanksgiving. They couldn’t wait. They regaled me with stories of family traditions and exotic-sounding food I’d never tried (cranberry sauce) and in some cases never even heard of (green bean casserole).
2017-11-18.headline_main: How First-Generation College Students Do Thanksgiving Break

2017-11-18.abstract: They need our help, not an easier way to make their carcasses into trophies.
2017-11-18.snippet: They need our help, not an easier way to make their carcasses into trophies.
2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been haunted by a photo. In it, a mother elephant and her baby are running across a road in West Bengal, India. The mother has her head down and ears forward, heading for safety in the trees. A ball of fire clings to her right foot; her tail appears singed. The baby’s hind legs are engulfed in flames. In the background, a crowd of men is running away, some pausing to gape and jeer over their shoulders. They are the reason for the fire. They have thrown firecrackers and balls of flaming tar at the animals. The image, taken by Biplab Hazra and chosen by the Indian conservation group Sanctuary Asia as this year’s winner of its annual wildlife photography contest, is titled “Hell Is Here.”
2017-11-18.headline_main: Why Can’t We Protect Elephants?

2017-11-18.abstract: There is no easy fix for Republican leaders now, whether their bill passes or fails.

2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: In January, I started writing a novel in which a 10-kiloton nuclear bomb was detonated in the center of Washington, where I live. It was meant to be funny. I had read a 2011 report by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that described the effect of such a detonation, and was surprised to learn that my apartment in Adams Morgan would most likely survive the initial blast.

2017-11-18.lead_paragraph: A decade ago I bought my first smartphone, a clunky little BlackBerry 8830 that came in a sleek black leather sheath. I loved that phone. I loved the way it effortlessly slid in and out of its case, loved the soft purr it emitted when an email came in, loved the silent whoosh of its trackball as I played Brick Breaker on the subway and the feel of its baby keys clicking under my fat thumbs. It was the world in my hands, and when I had to turn it off, I felt anxious and alone.
2017-11-18.headline_main: Our Love Affair With Digital Is Over

2017-11-19.abstract: A young woman who grew up in Zimbabwe now sits thousands of miles away, glued to Twitter. “We have yet to see what this new day brings, but we are ready for change,” she says.
2017-11-19.snippet: A young woman who grew up in Zimbabwe now sits thousands of miles away, glued to Twitter. “We have yet to see what this new day brings, but we are ready for change,” she says.
2017-11-19.lead_paragraph: I couldn’t sleep. I follow twimbos (Zimbabwean Twitter users) and am part of several WhatsApp groups, none of which has anything to do with politics; yet all were a flurry of news — real or fake. Family members on the ground were less sure of what was happening, while those in the diaspora were supplying the information. It was surreal.
2017-11-19.headline_main: ‘The Zimbabwe of My Youth Is No More’

2017-11-19.abstract: The musician, who died on Saturday, gave the band its architectural foundation, using his rhythm guitar to make AC/DC swing as much as it stomped.
2017-11-19.snippet: The musician, who died on Saturday, gave the band its architectural foundation, using his rhythm guitar to make AC/DC swing as much as it stomped.
2017-11-19.lead_paragraph: Malcolm Young, who died on Saturday at 64, was the self-effacing guitarist in AC/DC, the one who stood back while his brother Angus ran around arena stages in schoolboy knickers, brandishing a flashy lead guitar. But it was Malcolm who gave the band its architectural foundation, forging many of its best power-chorded riffs and cagily using his rhythm guitar to make AC/DC swing as much as it stomped. Here are 10 songs that reveal his essential role in the band.
2017-11-19.headline_main: Malcolm Young of AC/DC: Listen to 10 Essential Songs

2017-11-19.lead_paragraph: Harper Ediger has lived out a familiar adolescent nightmare: being excluded. “I won’t sugarcoat it: Feeling left out sucks,” Harper, a 14-year-old Denver native, writes in a new kids-centric advice column for The New York Times. “When you feel left out, consider that perhaps your friends felt you wouldn’t enjoy the activity they were doing, or they knew you were busy that night. Don’t assume your friends’ intentions.”

2017-11-19.abstract: David Hepworth discusses “Uncommon People,” his new book about Bob Dylan, David Bowie and many others who shaped our idea of what a rock star is — and about why that species has disappeared.
2017-11-19.snippet: David Hepworth discusses “Uncommon People,” his new book about Bob Dylan, David Bowie and many others who shaped our idea of what a rock star is — and about why that species has disappeared.
2017-11-19.lead_paragraph: The British music journalist David Hepworth’s “Never a Dull Moment” (2016) offered a very close look at the year 1971, a peak moment in rock ‘n’ roll history. His new book, “Uncommon People,” takes in the genre through a broader lens, 1955 to 1995, charting the rise and fall of the rock star as a species over that time. Below, Mr. Hepworth talks about how he won life’s lottery as a music fan, how social media helped make rock stars extinct, the reasons he admires Bruce Springsteen and more.
2017-11-19.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: The Era and Extinction of Rock Stars

2017-11-19.lead_paragraph: The Temporary Protected Status program provides the sort of assistance the United States should be proud to extend to foreigners fleeing civil unrest, violence or natural disasters. Enacted by Congress in 1990, it currently offers safe and legal harbor to 437,000 people from 10 countries. Many stay for a long time, their status regularly extended because of continued turmoil in their homelands.

2017-11-19.abstract: All these dead spaces hurt, and neighborhoods have a right to protect themselves.
2017-11-19.snippet: All these dead spaces hurt, and neighborhoods have a right to protect themselves.
2017-11-19.lead_paragraph: In his classic 1949 essay “Here Is New York,” E. B. White described the city as “a composite of tens of thousands of tiny neighborhood units,” each “virtually self-sufficient” with shops that met most residents’ basic needs, from groceries to shoes, from newspapers to haircuts. Every neighborhood was so complete, White wrote, “that many a New Yorker spends a lifetime within the confines of an area smaller than a country village.”
2017-11-19.headline_main: Why Is New York Full of Empty Stores?

2017-11-20.abstract: It has no incentive to do so. I would know — I worked there.
2017-11-20.snippet: It has no incentive to do so. I would know — I worked there.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: I led Facebook’s efforts to fix privacy problems on its developer platform in advance of its 2012 initial public offering. What I saw from the inside was a company that prioritized data collection from its users over protecting them from abuse. As the world contemplates what to do about Facebook in the wake of its role in Russia’s election meddling, it must consider this history. Lawmakers shouldn’t allow Facebook to regulate itself. Because it won’t.
2017-11-20.headline_main: We Can’t Trust Facebook to Regulate Itself

2017-11-20.headline_main: Nascar Season Ends at a Crossroad With Star Drivers Departing

2017-11-20.abstract: Was a doctor conducting leprosy experiments on patients without their consent?
2017-11-20.snippet: Was a doctor conducting leprosy experiments on patients without their consent?
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Last year I published a book, “Blood in the Water,” that offered the first comprehensive account of the uprising at New York’s Attica Correctional Facility in 1971 and its legacy. Though this protest against systematic abuse and abysmal living conditions — in which nearly 1,300 prisoners took over the facility, and law enforcement ultimately shot 128 men, killing 39 — was a cultural and political touchstone of the 1970s, much of the story was covered up. Attica is a public institution, but its records are not easily accessible. With no statute of limitations on murder, state officials had much to protect.
2017-11-20.headline_main: Attica: It’s Worse Than We Thought

2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: “Evolution Mama” is a sassy song dating back many decades, probably best played on a banjo, maybe with a kazoo in the background. “Evolution mama,” it goes, “don’t you make a monkey out of me.” That certainly captures the sentiments of religious groups and like-minded politicians who believe Charles Darwin was talking through his hat and there is no way that humans are descended from lower animals.

2017-11-20.abstract: This week’s episode gave Claire one of her most frustrating challenges yet.
2017-11-20.snippet: This week’s episode gave Claire one of her most frustrating challenges yet.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: One of the things “Outlander” has always done well is to make sure that Claire doesn’t have the 20th-century advantage. Time and again, she runs up against how hard it is for her to actually be of any use in the past, even with a modern education. There are so many moving parts that even anticipating the outcome is a gamble. And trying to affect the outcome, more often than not, turns her into a Cassandra. This week’s episode gives Claire one of her most frustrating challenges yet, trapping her at sea on the Porpoise in the midst of a typhoid fever outbreak.
2017-11-20.headline_main: ‘Outlander’ Season 3 Episode 10: How Many Would You Like Me to Save?

2017-11-20.snippet: Robert Mugabe’s rule in Zimbabwe went unchallenged for 37 years, but in just a few days, he was largely stripped of power. The chain of events leading to his fall started with firing a vice president.

2017-11-20.abstract: An unconventional Primary Stages adaptation of the Jane Austen novel features gags, dance breaks and other cynical silliness.
2017-11-20.snippet: An unconventional Primary Stages adaptation of the Jane Austen novel features gags, dance breaks and other cynical silliness.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: “Pride and Prejudice” at Primary Stages is not your typical Jane Austen dramatization. There are no lavish balls, no sumptuous Regency gowns, few melting glances. Mr. Darcy’s shirt stays resolutely dry. Which is all to the good; pecs were never really Austen’s thing. As for the speed and the gags and the dance breaks, well, purists might want to keep some lavender drops handy.

2017-11-20.abstract: Negan makes a rare “confession.” He’s anything but contrite.
2017-11-20.snippet: Negan makes a rare “confession.” He’s anything but contrite.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: This season’s war has ushered Negan into a role somewhere between cult leader and military commander, both of which require people skills. Negan has flashed his talents as a public orator time and again, whipping his followers into a bloodthirsty frenzy with speeches delivered in the dramatic, halting cadence of Mussolini. In this week’s episode, he works his powers of persuasion on a more intimate level, and in doing so, he opens himself up a bit as well. But in the sliver of his interior revealed through his candid heart-to-heart with Gabriel, there’s only megalomania and delusion.
2017-11-20.headline_main: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 8, Episode 5: A Fruitless Death

2017-11-20.snippet: An Op-Ed columnist explains what Australia’s ‘yes’ vote for same-sex marriage reveals about the nation’s character.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: When a government official announced on Australian national television on Wednesday that 61.6 percent of participants in a nonbinding nationwide survey had said “yes” to same-sex marriage, thousands of people gathered in public to celebrate. They hugged, cried and danced to “Love Is in the Air.” Some rushed to post Instagram photos of themselves holding a Golden Gaytime, a nostalgic Australian ice-cream brand.
2017-11-20.headline_main: ‘Toxic Masculinity’ Has Slowed Australia’s March to Same-Sex Marriage

2017-11-20.abstract: Doctors walk a difficult line as they try to discuss the fraught subject of weight without increasing the distress that many children already feel.
2017-11-20.snippet: Doctors walk a difficult line as they try to discuss the fraught subject of weight without increasing the distress that many children already feel.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: I weigh my words (pun intended) every time I address the topic of a child’s obesity in the exam room. Yes, I know, you probably want to tell me that I shouldn’t use that word — “obese” — and I promise that I don’t. But in the child’s electronic medical record, that’s the official coding if the child’s body mass index is at or above the 95th percentile for age and gender. And medical providers, just like parents, may find themselves walking a difficult line as they try to discuss this fraught subject without increasing the distress that many children are already feeling.
2017-11-20.headline_main: How Not to Talk to a Child Who Is Overweight

2017-11-20.abstract: This fall, the balance of that power has shifted, with exhilarating, destabilizing results.
2017-11-20.snippet: This fall, the balance of that power has shifted, with exhilarating, destabilizing results.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: For a town so in love with doomsday scenarios, Hollywood has never been big on revelations about itself. That’s what apocalypse is, literally: disclosure of knowledge. In biblical Greek, “apokalypsis” means “uncovering” or “unveiling.” It refers to the moment when a long-buried truth is finally exposed. The secret could be anything — a plague of worms; corruption; a culture of flagrant harassment, exploitation and abuse. What actually ends the world as we know it is the revelation itself, being shown the thing we had agreed not to see. Once we see that civilization had it coming, we can consign everything to the purifying flames.
2017-11-20.headline_main: ‘Exposure’ Is About Truth, Sure, but Mostly About Power

2017-11-20.abstract: The former United States attorney on not being part of “the resistance” and what he’ll do if President Trump gets impeached.
2017-11-20.snippet: The former United States attorney on not being part of “the resistance” and what he’ll do if President Trump gets impeached.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: You went from being the most famous and powerful United States attorney in the country to hosting a weekly podcast about justice. No offense, but some people might consider that a slight step down. Wow. How much of a descent is that? Look, if I had never become the United States attorney, I would have lived a full and happy and unregretful life. The happiest day of my professional life was becoming an assistant U.S. attorney, because I always wanted to have a position where the only job is to do the right thing. Becoming U.S. attorney was gravy on top of all that. But at some point, you’ve got to leave.
2017-11-20.headline_main: Preet Bharara Is Not Running for Office

2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: My closest American friend here in Japan, of more than 30 years, is worried about me and wants to pay off my mortgages. He says he doesn’t want to be paid back; he just wants to make sure I am out of debt before he dies. He is not dying, but he is 98. He has been mentioning this more and more, and says he wants to write a check the next time we meet. I never talk about this with him unless he brings up the subject. The amount he would give me would come to about 3 percent of his assets. It would have no impact on his financial needs. And frankly, it would be helpful for me.
2017-11-20.headline_main: Can I Let My Friend Pay Off My Mortgages?

2017-11-20.abstract: Beijing has fully embraced the concept — but in ways that show just how cynical it can become.
2017-11-20.snippet: Beijing has fully embraced the concept — but in ways that show just how cynical it can become.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: For decades after its Communist revolution in 1949, China was known as “the kingdom of bicycles.” The one-speed Flying Pigeons that swarmed the streets were not simply a cheap mode of transportation. They were symbols of a shared aspiration. Along with a radio, a watch and a sewing machine, a bicycle was one of four possessions — known as sanzhuan yixiang, or “three rounds and sound” — that urban Chinese families felt they needed to be part of the modern world. By the time I joined the masses in 2001, cycling across Beijing for daily Mandarin classes, cars had begun to displace bicycles. Pedaling alongside my fellow commuters — students, workers, pensioners — I felt part of a communal experience that might soon be gone forever.
2017-11-20.headline_main: China’s Revealing Spin on the ‘Sharing Economy’

2017-11-20.abstract: In an expansion of the war on drugs, the U.S. Coast Guard is targeting low-level smugglers in international waters — shackling them on ships for weeks or even months before arraignment in American courts.
2017-11-20.snippet: In an expansion of the war on drugs, the U.S. Coast Guard is targeting low-level smugglers in international waters — shackling them on ships for weeks or even months before arraignment in American courts.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: On nights when the November rain poured down and he had not slept at all, Jhonny Arcentales had visions of dying, of his body being cast into the dark ocean. He would imagine his wife and their teenage son tossing his clothes into a pit in a cemetery and gathering at the local church for his funeral. It had been more than two months since Arcentales, a 40-year-old fisherman from Ecuador’s central coast, left home, telling his wife he would return in five days. A cuff clamped onto his ankle kept him shackled to a cable along the deck of the ship but for the occasional trip, guarded by a sailor, to defecate into a bucket. Most of the time, he couldn’t move more than an arm’s length in either direction without jostling the next shackled man. “The sea used to be freedom,” he told me. But on the ship, “it was the opposite. Like a prison in the open ocean.”
2017-11-20.headline_main: The Coast Guard’s ‘Floating Guantánamos’

Barrie original, created and performed by a six-member ensemble. The director, Eric Tucker, specializes in small-cast, big-idea takes on the classics, but this attempt is both a puzzle and a bummer — too childish to tell the story properly and too adult to access its wonder.

2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: In “Diaspora,” a muddle of a play by Nathaniel Sam Shapiro at the Gym at Judson, a group of American Jews on a Birthright trip to Israel drink, hook up and occasionally visit a few historical sights, like Yad Vashem, the museum of the Holocaust, where, as one girl confesses, “I don’t know, I was kind of turned on,” and Masada, the site of an armed resistance that ended in murder and suicide. 2017-11-20.snippet: The Kitchen by W&P Design, a shop open to the end of the year in NoLIta, has gifts and special tasting events.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: For five years, Eric Prum and Josh Williams have sold cocktail equipment, goods for entertaining and clever books online. Now they have opened a bright pop-up boutique. You will find cocktail shakers, bottle openers, bar and cheese knives, items for travel, books and games, little denim napkins and compact ice cube trays. Drink and dessert tastings are scheduled during the run of the shop, through the end of the year: The Kitchen by W&P Design, 171 Elizabeth Street (Spring Street), no phone, wandpdesign.com.
2017-11-20.headline_main: Online Cocktail-Equipment Shop Opens a Pop-Up

2017-11-20.abstract: Culatello di Zibello, a cured meat from Parma, is now available in America.
2017-11-20.snippet: Culatello di Zibello, a cured meat from Parma, is now available in America.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: There is prosciutto, and then there is culatello. To connoisseurs, the latter — cured from a solid chunk of leg, not the whole leg like standard prosciutto — is the variety worth seeking now that the Department of Agriculture has approved for import the culatello di Zibello made near Parma by the Negroni company. For culatello, the meat of black nera di Parma pigs is rubbed with salt, black pepper and garlic, painstakingly tied, wrapped in a pig’s bladder and then allowed to cure in cellars. The rosy slices, rounded in shape, have a vein of pinkish fat up the middle. The aroma is ever so lightly funky, the texture is silky and the taste is briny sweet, less delicate than prosciutto di Parma: Culatello di Zibello, $60 a pound, DiPalo’s Fine Foods, 200 Grand Street (Mott Street), 212-226-1033.
2017-11-20.headline_main: When You Need to Impress Your Italian Relatives

2017-11-20.abstract: Gruyère d’Alpage is made the traditional way with summer milk from cows that forage in the Alps.
2017-11-20.snippet: Gruyère d’Alpage is made the traditional way with summer milk from cows that forage in the Alps.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: In western Switzerland, Philippe Pasquier — whose company, Le Jeu de Quilles, was established in 1723 — still makes his small-batch Gruyère the old-fashioned way, using raw summer milk from cows that forage in the mountains. The system of grazing is called alpage, or transhumance, by which the cattle follow the grasses, herbs and flowers as they develop at increasingly higher altitudes (at least 2,900 feet during the season). The washed-rind cheeses are aged 14 months. This particular Gruyère is now available in the Northeast from FreshDirect. The cheese has a rich, herbal aroma and sweet nuttiness, and texture enhanced with a delicate crystalline crunch, a token of aging. Serve it as is, or use it in scores of recipes: Gruyère d’Alpage, $27.99 a pound, freshdirect.com.
2017-11-20.headline_main: An Alpine Cheese for Special Occasions

2017-11-20.abstract: “On Jews and Chocolate” at Temple Emanu-El’s Judaica museum looks at a history that can be traced back to Europe.
2017-11-20.snippet: “On Jews and Chocolate” at Temple Emanu-El’s Judaica museum looks at a history that can be traced back to Europe.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: The connection between Jews and chocolate goes beyond Hanukkah gelt. Jewish refugees were instrumental in establishing chocolate companies in America, and before that, they were chocolatiers in France, Austria and other countries. An exhibition of artifacts and other materials sheds light on this history: “On Jews and Chocolate,” Sundays to Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., to Feb. 25, 2018; Herbert and Eileen Bernard Museum of Judaica, Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street (Fifth Avenue), 212-744-1400, extension 259, emanuelnyc.org/museum.php.
2017-11-20.headline_main: A Connection Beyond Hanukkah Gelt

2017-11-20.abstract: The collapse of coalition talks on Sunday doesn’t mean the country is collapsing. But it does show how much the far right has changed German politics.
2017-11-20.snippet: The collapse of coalition talks on Sunday doesn’t mean the country is collapsing. But it does show how much the far right has changed German politics.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was the most preposterous mic drop in German history. On Sunday night, after 56 days of four-party talks on forming a coalition government, the pro-business Free Democratic Party abruptly pulled out of the negotiations, effectively ending them.
2017-11-20.headline_main: Germany and the Age of Political Absolutism

2017-11-20.abstract: Sealed in green wax, Pinhook Straight Rye Whiskey is earthy with a finish that channels tarte Tatin.
2017-11-20.snippet: Sealed in green wax, Pinhook Straight Rye Whiskey is earthy with a finish that channels tarte Tatin.
2017-11-20.lead_paragraph: Sean Josephs, a founder of Maysville in NoMad and Kenton’s in New Orleans, is a brown-spirits aficionado. He is also a partner in the company behind Pinhook bourbon. The brand has released a smooth, earthy straight rye whiskey, with a finish that channels tarte Tatin. Try it in his El Caballero, a cocktail made for the tapas bar Tia Pol. Measure two ounces of Pinhook rye, a half-ounce each of sweet sherry and Punt e Mes, and two dashes each of Angostura and orange bitters. Mix together with ice until very cold. Strain into a cocktail glass or over a big cube, and garnish with orange peel. The drink is easily expanded to a party-size quantity: Pinhook Straight Rye Whiskey, $37.99 for 750 milliliters, flatiron-wines.com.
2017-11-20.headline_main: A Rye Whiskey Dressed Up and Ready to Give

Nor, despite their best intentions, do Mr. Trump and his former adviser Steve Bannon.

2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: As he raised estate tax rates to fund work programs during the Great Depression, Franklin Delano Roosevelt said, “The transmission from generation to generation of vast fortunes by will, inheritance or gift is not consistent with the ideals and sentiments of the American people.”

2017-11-21.abstract: The case of Al Franken shows how painful and confusing it is when the #MeToo juggernaut comes for men we respect.
2017-11-21.snippet: The case of Al Franken shows how painful and confusing it is when the #MeToo juggernaut comes for men we respect.
2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, after a photograph emerged of Senator Al Franken either groping or pretending to grope a sleeping woman, Leeann Tweeden, with whom he’d been traveling on a 2006 U.S.O. tour, I wrote that he should resign. Almost as soon as it was published I started having second thoughts. I spent all weekend feeling guilty that I’d called for the sacrifice of an otherwise decent man to make a political point.
2017-11-21.headline_main: When Our Allies Are Accused of Harassment

2017-11-21.abstract: The Supreme Court has narrowed the use of life sentences without parole for juveniles. Now it can end it for good.

2017-11-21.abstract: In 1967 the White House undertook a massive P.R. campaign on the Vietnam War. It worked — too well.
2017-11-21.snippet: In 1967 the White House undertook a massive P.R. campaign on the Vietnam War. It worked — too well.
2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: In 1967, the expensive and bloody war in Vietnam was not obviously producing an American victory. Journalists and politicians began to speak of a stalemate. President Lyndon Johnson, and the men leading the American effort in Vietnam, found this intolerable. They felt that maintaining public support for the war required persuading the press and the public that the war was being won. And so, that fall, they undertook what has sometimes been called the “Optimism Campaign.”
2017-11-21.headline_main: Lyndon Johnson’s War Propaganda

2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: The flight attendant passing a tomato juice to my seatmate did a double-take when she saw my tear-streaked face. She touched my shoulder: “Ma’am, are you doing O.K.?” I wiped the gobs of snot from my nose, pulled my headphones off and gave her that awkward, forced smile you do when you’re crying but want the other person to leave you alone. She obliged.
2017-11-21.headline_main: Letter of Recommendation: In-Flight Movies

2017-11-21.abstract: As machine learning becomes more powerful, the field’s researchers increasingly find themselves unable to account for what their algorithms know — or how they know it.
2017-11-21.snippet: As machine learning becomes more powerful, the field’s researchers increasingly find themselves unable to account for what their algorithms know — or how they know it.
2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: In September, Michal Kosinski published a study that he feared might end his career. The Economist broke the news first, giving it a self-consciously anodyne title: “Advances in A.I. Are Used to Spot Signs of Sexuality.” But the headlines quickly grew more alarmed. By the next day, the Human Rights Campaign and Glaad, formerly known as the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, had labeled Kosinski’s work “dangerous” and “junk science.” (They claimed it had not been peer reviewed, though it had.) In the next week, the tech-news site The Verge had run an article that, while carefully reported, was nonetheless topped with a scorching headline: “The Invention of A.I. ‘Gaydar’ Could Be the Start of Something Much Worse.”
2017-11-21.headline_main: Can A.I. Be Taught to Explain Itself?

2017-11-21.abstract: After more than three decades as a provocateur, the filmmaker has returned to the movie that made him famous.
2017-11-21.snippet: After more than three decades as a provocateur, the filmmaker has returned to the movie that made him famous.
2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: Before he had even made his first movie, Spike Lee used to fantasize about three things: season tickets at the Garden, a brownstone in Fort Greene like the one that he was raised in and a house in the historically black Oak Bluffs section of Martha’s Vineyard. In 1986, after writing, producing, directing and acting in his infectious debut, “She’s Gotta Have It,” a stylish, edgy rom-com about a libidinous young woman juggling three lovers, those Knicks seats came first. The two homes swiftly followed, and within a decade, Lee’s status and celebrity had catapulted him, practically against his will, from Da Republic of Brooklyn, as he likes to call it in emails, into a 8,200-square-foot Upper East Side townhouse that was previously home to Jasper Johns. But the getaway in Massachusetts, situated next to the 18th hole at the Farm Neck Golf Club, has never required upgrading.
2017-11-21.headline_main: The Culture Caught Up With Spike Lee — Now What?

2017-11-21.snippet: Some hotels are offering record players, along with impressive vinyl collections to go with them.
2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: When Schafer Newman stayed at the Goodland, in Goleta, Calif., last year, it wasn’t the hotel’s proximity to the beach or downtown Santa Barbara that impressed him the most. Nor was it the extensive cocktail and spirits list at the property’s watering hole, the Good Bar. While these features were welcome, Mr. Newman, 28, from San Diego, said that he was blown away by the record player in his room, accompanied by a selection of rock ‘n’ roll records, including “Let It Bleed” by the Rolling Stones. “I had never used a record player, much less really seen one before, and I thought it was the coolest touch,” he said.

2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: The amount of advice for traveling with kids can be overwhelming. But like most of us grown-ups, children often become good travelers through a lucky mix of nature and nurture: Some kids are flexible, some crave a routine, and some are just completely thrown off kilter by the travails of delayed planes, any change in schedule, and jet lag.

2017-11-21.abstract: A bonding activity that builds joy and character.
2017-11-21.snippet: A bonding activity that builds joy and character.
2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: There’s a picture that I keep in the left-hand corner of my computer screen, of me and my son, Joshua, who is now grown, baking together years ago. It shows me bent over the kitchen counter gingerly disengaging a bell-shaped cookie from a large piece of dough. It looks as if it might have been gingerbread. Joshua — age uncertain, less than 3, I’d say — is standing on the stool we bought for just this job. He’s holding a cookie cutter, and there are more scattered about. We both have flour on our fingers; Joshua has some in his hair and on his sleeve, too. We’re both concentrating intently.
2017-11-21.headline_main: What Children — and Parents — Can Learn From Baking Together

2017-11-21.abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2017-11-21.snippet: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
2017-11-21.lead_paragraph: SPACEPORT EARTH By Joe Pappalardo. (Overlook Press, $28.95.) Private companies and rich people like Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos have taken over the exploration of space. Pappalardo explores this new sort of spacefaring at the outer reaches of business and technology. HIGHBROW, LOWBROW, BRILLIANT, DESPICABLE: 50 YEARS OF NEW YORK By the Editors of New York Magazine. (Simon & Schuster, $65.) With irreverence and spunk, New York magazine has been around for half a century now. This very big book includes an oral history of the publication and a wide look at its greatest moments. BALCONY IN THE FOREST By Julien Gracq. (New York Review Books, $15.95.) A French author known for the dreamlike quality of his writing, Gracq was also a novelist who could capture well the sensation of waiting. This 1958 novel about French soldiers living in the Ardennes forest at the start of World War II, in anticipation of the German incursion, is a perfect example. SECRECY WORLD By Jake Bernstein. (Henry Holt, $30.) The infamous Panama Papers revealed for the world how superwealthy people and celebrities hide their money. In this financial exposé, we get all the details on shell companies and offshore accounts. REVOLUTION By Emmanuel Macron. (Scribe, $16.95.) France’s new president, the youngest in the history of the country, has been an object of fascination ever since he unexpectedly came to power. In this political autobiography, he recounts his origins and explains his centrist philosophy.
2017-11-21.headline_main: New & Noteworthy

When they reached the chorus — “How sweet it is to live in one house, how sweet to live in one hometown” — one of the singers, Safana Baqleh, began to weep into her hands.

Many parents probably hope that shiny new technologies, such as Fitbits and other physical-activity monitors, might inspire our children to become more active.

Oh, I realize, I am still learning from my deceased parents.
